cluster_classes.class_description: Scientific disciplines that provide foundational methods and knowledge for forensic science, including analysis of biological, chemical, physical, and quantitative aspects of evidence.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: forensic science combines various scientific disciplines such as biology, chemistry, physics, and mathematics to analyze physical evidence

members.entity_description: Scientific discipline used in forensic science to analyze biological aspects of evidence.
Scientific discipline used in forensic science to study chemical properties of evidence.
Scientific discipline contributing analytical methods to forensic science.
Scientific discipline used in forensic science, for example in statistics and pattern analysis.

cluster_classes.class_description: Core conceptual and procedural elements that underpin forensic science practice, including foundational principles and the scientific and investigative methods used to analyze evidence.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Application of scientific methods and principles combined with investigative techniques within forensic science.

members.entity_description: Systematic methods and technical procedures used within forensic science to analyze evidence.
Foundational scientific concepts and laws applied within forensic science investigations.
Methods and procedures used to investigate and analyze evidence in forensic cases.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts and methods related to the conduct and evolution of forensic science as a discipline, including its techniques and overarching practice.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: As technology continues to advance and new techniques are developed, the art of forensic science will only become more sophisticated...

members.entity_description: Emerging methods and procedures developed to improve forensic analysis and investigation.
The combined practice, methodology, and skill involved in conducting forensic science.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts describing the overall competence and specialized knowledge required to conduct forensic science effectively.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The art of forensic science requires not only technical expertise...

members.entity_description: Conceptual view of forensic science as a disciplined, skillful practice combining technique and careful thought.
Specialized scientific and procedural knowledge required to conduct forensic analysis effectively.

cluster_classes.class_description: Mental skills needed to evaluate evidence rigorously in forensic work, including reasoning and meticulous observation.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: requires not only technical expertise but also critical thinking skills and attention to detail

members.entity_description: Ability to reason logically and evaluate evidence when performing forensic work.
Careful focus on small but important aspects of evidence and procedures in forensic work.

cluster_classes.class_description: Technological tools, instruments, and broader technological advancements used to support the analysis and practice of forensic science.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: advanced technology and instrumentation used in the analysis of forensic evidence

members.entity_description: Specialized scientific instruments employed in the laboratory analysis of forensic evidence.
Tools, systems, and ongoing technological advancements that support and enhance forensic science analysis and practice.

cluster_classes.class_description: Academic and professional discipline focused on applying scientific methods and technology to the collection, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of evidence in legal and criminal investigations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: applies scientific methods, analysis, and technology to collect, analyze, interpret, and present evidence in criminal and legal investigations

members.entity_description: Interdisciplinary field that applies scientific methods, analysis, and technology to collect, analyze, interpret, and present evidence in criminal and legal investigations.

cluster_classes.class_description: Professionals who apply scientific methods to collect, analyze, and interpret evidence in criminal and forensic investigations, including support for crime scene work and court proceedings.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: profession of forensic science practitioners ... in crime and evidence analysis

members.entity_description: Professionals who apply scientific methods and technologies to collect, analyze, interpret, and present evidence in criminal and forensic investigations, often assisting crime scene work and court proceedings.

cluster_classes.class_description: A non-specific future interval referenced in forward-looking statements or projections, such as expectations about advancements in forensic science.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the art of forensic science will only become more sophisticated and effective in the years to come

members.entity_description: An upcoming time period in which forensic science is expected to become more sophisticated and effective.

args.justification: The entity 'art of forensic science' is defined as a disciplined, skillful practice combining technique and careful thought, aligning more closely with overall forensic practice competence than with emerging techniques and general practice evolution.

This class groups core scientific disciplines (biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics) that underpin forensic science and should sit in a shared higher-level group with other domain-structure classes.
Forensic Science Foundations describes core conceptual and procedural elements of forensic science and belongs with other classes modeling the forensic science domain itself.
Forensic Science Practice covers how the discipline is conducted and evolves, a core aspect of the forensic science domain rather than a separate competency-only area.
Forensic Technology describes tools and technological advancements used in forensic analysis, fitting as a structural component of the overall forensic science domain.
This class explicitly defines forensic science as a field of study and should anchor the broader 'Forensic Science Domain' group.
Forensic Scientists are the practitioner role within the forensic science field and naturally belong under the same high-level forensic science domain grouping.

Forensic Practice Competence focuses on the competence and specialized knowledge required of practitioners and should be grouped with other professional skill/competency classes rather than general domain structure.

Forensic Cognitive Skills covers specific mental skills (critical thinking, attention to detail) required in forensic work and should be grouped with broader forensic professional competence concepts.

Future Time Period models a generic temporal expression ('years to come') and is conceptually distinct from forensic science domain or competency classes, so it should be grouped under a generic temporal references class group.

executed_decisions.justification: The entity 'art of forensic science' is defined as a disciplined, skillful practice combining technique and careful thought, aligning more closely with overall forensic practice competence than with emerging techniques and general practice evolution.

This class groups core scientific disciplines (biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics) that underpin forensic science and should sit in a shared higher-level group with other domain-structure classes.
Forensic Science Foundations describes core conceptual and procedural elements of forensic science and belongs with other classes modeling the forensic science domain itself.
Forensic Science Practice covers how the discipline is conducted and evolves, a core aspect of the forensic science domain rather than a separate competency-only area.
Forensic Technology describes tools and technological advancements used in forensic analysis, fitting as a structural component of the overall forensic science domain.
This class explicitly defines forensic science as a field of study and should anchor the broader 'Forensic Science Domain' group.
Forensic Scientists are the practitioner role within the forensic science field and naturally belong under the same high-level forensic science domain grouping.

Forensic Practice Competence focuses on the competence and specialized knowledge required of practitioners and should be grouped with other professional skill/competency classes rather than general domain structure.

Forensic Cognitive Skills covers specific mental skills (critical thinking, attention to detail) required in forensic work and should be grouped with broader forensic professional competence concepts.

Future Time Period models a generic temporal expression ('years to come') and is conceptually distinct from forensic science domain or competency classes, so it should be grouped under a generic temporal references class group.

cluster_classes.class_description: Roles and organizations that participate in the legal process by using, receiving, or presenting forensic findings, including enforcement, advocacy, adjudication, and expert testimony.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: communicate their findings effectively to law enforcement agencies, lawyers, and judges, often testifying as expert witnesses in court

members.entity_description: Organizations responsible for enforcing laws, receiving forensic findings and interpretations.
Legal professionals who use forensic findings in litigation and courtroom proceedings.
Judicial officers who hear forensic expert testimony and evaluate presented evidence.
Forensic specialists testifying in court to explain analyses and conclusions.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concrete criminal occurrences and their temporal structure, including the crime itself, the actual happenings, and the ordered sequence leading up to the offense.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: reconstruct the events that took place and ... the sequence of events leading up to a crime

members.entity_description: Unlawful acts that forensic science helps to investigate, reconstruct, and address within the criminal justice system.
The actual occurrences at or around the time of the crime that forensic scientists seek to reconstruct.

members.entity_name: sequence of events leading up to a crime
members.entity_description: Ordered chain of actions and occurrences culminating in the commission of a crime.

cluster_classes.class_description: Institutional processes and structures involved in responding to crime, including the criminal justice system and the investigation and prosecution of crimes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: plays a crucial role in the criminal justice system ... investigation and prosecution of crimes

members.entity_description: The system of law enforcement, courts, and corrections that administers criminal law and justice.
Process of examining crimes where forensic science provides valuable evidence.
Legal process of bringing criminal charges, supported by forensic evidence.

cluster_classes.class_description: Normative social outcomes related to fairness in the legal context, encompassing both justice and injustice that forensic science seeks to achieve or prevent.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: a powerful tool in the fight against crime and injustice... ensuring that justice is served

members.entity_description: Unfair or wrongful outcomes that forensic science aims to help correct or prevent.
The legal and moral outcome where appropriate consequences are applied based on evidence.

cluster_classes.class_description: Human participants in the criminal justice process, including those who investigate crimes and those found guilty and held accountable.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: help investigators ... ensuring that justice is served and that the guilty are held accountable

members.entity_description: Individuals responsible for investigating crimes, assisted by forensic reconstructions and evidence.
Persons found responsible for crimes who are subject to accountability.

cluster_classes.class_description: Actions and conduct of individuals found guilty within legal or forensic contexts, focusing on behaviors that are evaluated for accountability and justice processes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: ensuring that justice is served and that the guilty are held accountable for their actions

members.entity_description: Behavior or conduct of offenders that is evaluated within forensic and legal processes.

args.new_description: Human and organizational participants in the criminal justice and legal process, including law enforcement, legal professionals, investigators, judges, expert witnesses, and offenders who are held accountable.
args.justification: Both classes consist of human or organizational actors who participate in investigation, adjudication, or accountability within the criminal justice process, so they represent the same conceptual space and should be unified.

args.new_description: Human and organizational participants in the criminal justice and legal process, including law enforcement, legal professionals, investigators, judges, expert witnesses, and offenders who are held accountable.
args.justification: The merged participant class belongs in the overarching domain of criminal justice and forensic science, which connects it to related event, process, and outcome classes.
Crime events and their temporal structure are core elements of the same criminal justice and forensic domain as the participant and process classes, so they should share a common Class_Group.
Criminal justice processes such as investigation and prosecution are central mechanisms within the same overarching criminal justice and forensic context.
Justice and injustice are normative outcomes specifically discussed in relation to crime and forensic science, so they should be grouped under the same criminal justice and forensic domain.

Offender behavior (actions of guilty individuals) is evaluated within forensic and legal processes and belongs in the same high-level criminal justice and forensic context as events, processes, and participants.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes consist of human or organizational actors who participate in investigation, adjudication, or accountability within the criminal justice process, so they represent the same conceptual space and should be unified.

executed_decisions.new_description: Human and organizational participants in the criminal justice and legal process, including law enforcement, legal professionals, investigators, judges, expert witnesses, and offenders who are held accountable.
executed_decisions.justification: The merged participant class belongs in the overarching domain of criminal justice and forensic science, which connects it to related event, process, and outcome classes.
Crime events and their temporal structure are core elements of the same criminal justice and forensic domain as the participant and process classes, so they should share a common Class_Group.
Criminal justice processes such as investigation and prosecution are central mechanisms within the same overarching criminal justice and forensic context.
Justice and injustice are normative outcomes specifically discussed in relation to crime and forensic science, so they should be grouped under the same criminal justice and forensic domain.

Offender behavior (actions of guilty individuals) is evaluated within forensic and legal processes and belongs in the same high-level criminal justice and forensic context as events, processes, and participants.

cluster_classes.class_description: Laboratory and instrumental methods used to analyze forensic evidence, including microscopy, spectroscopy, chromatography, and DNA profiling.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Forensic scientists use a variety of techniques to collect and analyze this evidence, including microscopy, spectroscopy, chromatography, and DNA profiling.

members.entity_description: Analytical technique using microscopes to examine small or detailed features of forensic evidence.
Technique analyzing light or electromagnetic interactions to identify materials in forensic samples.
Separation technique used to analyze mixtures and substances in forensic evidence.
Forensic technique for identifying individuals based on their unique genetic patterns.

cluster_classes.class_description: Chemical substances such as drugs and toxins that are specifically targeted for detection and quantification in forensic analyses.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: mass spectrometry to identify and quantify drugs or toxins in a sample

members.entity_description: Chemical substances, often controlled, whose presence and quantity in samples are analyzed for investigations.
Poisonous chemical substances that forensic scientists detect and measure in investigative samples.

cluster_classes.class_description: Devices used to perform detailed analysis and characterization of forensic evidence, including surface imaging and chemical identification.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: scanning electron microscopes to examine trace evidence ... use mass spectrometry to identify and quantify drugs or toxins

members.entity_description: High-resolution microscopes that use electron beams to examine the surface and structure of trace evidence.
Analytical technique used to identify and quantify chemical substances like drugs or toxins in samples.

args.justification: The entity 'mass spectrometry' is an analytical technique (InspectionMethod), aligning with other forensic analytical techniques like spectroscopy and chromatography in ClsC_b1faa47b rather than with physical instruments in ClsC_7757ff1e.

This class contains core forensic analytical methods (microscopy, spectroscopy, chromatography, DNA profiling, mass spectrometry) and should be grouped under a domain-level Class_Group that also covers related instruments and target substances.

This class represents analyte types (drugs, toxins) that are the targets of forensic analytical methods; assigning the same Class_Group connects it with the techniques and instruments used to detect them.

args.new_description: Devices used to perform detailed analysis and characterization of forensic evidence, such as scanning electron microscopes for surface imaging and structural examination.
args.justification: After moving the technique 'mass spectrometry' out, this class should focus on physical analytical instruments; updating the description and assigning the shared Class_Group clarifies its scope within the forensic analytical domain.

executed_decisions.justification: The entity 'mass spectrometry' is an analytical technique (InspectionMethod), aligning with other forensic analytical techniques like spectroscopy and chromatography in ClsC_b1faa47b rather than with physical instruments in ClsC_7757ff1e.

This class contains core forensic analytical methods (microscopy, spectroscopy, chromatography, DNA profiling, mass spectrometry) and should be grouped under a domain-level Class_Group that also covers related instruments and target substances.

This class represents analyte types (drugs, toxins) that are the targets of forensic analytical methods; assigning the same Class_Group connects it with the techniques and instruments used to detect them.

executed_decisions.new_description: Devices used to perform detailed analysis and characterization of forensic evidence, such as scanning electron microscopes for surface imaging and structural examination.
executed_decisions.justification: After moving the technique 'mass spectrometry' out, this class should focus on physical analytical instruments; updating the description and assigning the shared Class_Group clarifies its scope within the forensic analytical domain.

cluster_classes.class_description: Scientific and procedural workflows used to examine and interpret forensic evidence within criminal investigations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: forensic analysis... indispensable tool in modern criminal investigations... documenting every step of the analysis process

members.entity_description: Scientific examination and interpretation of evidence using forensic methods and technologies.
Ordered sequence of steps forensic scientists follow when examining and processing forensic evidence.
Contemporary investigative processes used by law enforcement to solve crimes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Measures that describe how well forensic examinations perform, focusing on correctness and consistency of results.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: technological advancements have greatly improved the accuracy and reliability of forensic analysis

members.entity_description: Degree to which forensic examination results correctly reflect the true state of evidence.
Consistency and dependability of forensic examination results across repeated analyses.

args.name: Criminal Investigation Processes
args.description: Procedural workflows and methods used by law enforcement and related agencies to investigate and solve crimes.
args.justification: The entity 'modern criminal investigations' describes general investigative processes, which are broader than and not specific to forensic analysis, so it should be its own class rather than grouped under forensic analysis processes.

Move 'modern criminal investigations' out of a forensic-analysis-specific class into a dedicated investigations process class, since it refers to broader investigative workflows beyond forensic examination.
Assign a stable Class_Group that captures the domain of forensic examination workflows after removing the general criminal investigation entity.

Connect the quality metrics for forensic analysis to the same higher-level forensic domain Class_Group as the forensic analysis processes, reflecting that they are distinct but closely related aspects of forensic science.

executed_decisions.justification: The entity 'modern criminal investigations' describes general investigative processes, which are broader than and not specific to forensic analysis, so it should be its own class rather than grouped under forensic analysis processes.

Move 'modern criminal investigations' out of a forensic-analysis-specific class into a dedicated investigations process class, since it refers to broader investigative workflows beyond forensic examination.
Assign a stable Class_Group that captures the domain of forensic examination workflows after removing the general criminal investigation entity.

Connect the quality metrics for forensic analysis to the same higher-level forensic domain Class_Group as the forensic analysis processes, reflecting that they are distinct but closely related aspects of forensic science.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts describing what forensic investigators analyze and reason about, including difficult investigative problems and subtle evidentiary indicators encountered during casework.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: think creatively and analytically ... to solve complex puzzles and uncover hidden clues

members.entity_description: Challenging investigative problems that forensic scientists work to resolve.
Subtle or non-obvious indicators in evidence that may be important for a case.

cluster_classes.class_description: Legal and investigative matters in which forensic science is applied, including individual cases, especially difficult or challenging ones, the legal issues arising from them, and the factual truth being sought.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: solve crimes and legal issues ... uncover the truth behind even the most challenging cases

members.entity_description: Legal disputes or questions addressed using forensic scientific evidence.
Individual investigative or legal matter that forensic work contributes to resolving.
The factual sequence of events and circumstances in difficult forensic investigations.
Difficult forensic or criminal investigations requiring advanced analysis and techniques.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes and outcomes involved in analyzing forensic evidence and deriving inferences, including interpretation of evidence, drawing logical conclusions, and articulating overall analysis and conclusions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: analyze complex data and draw logical conclusions based on the evidence... interpretation of evidence... explain their analysis and conclusions

members.entity_description: Process of analyzing and drawing meaning from collected forensic evidence.
Reasoned inferences derived from forensic data and evidence analysis.
Forensic scientists interpretive work and the final inferences derived from evidence.

cluster_classes.class_description: Acts of communicating forensic results, especially to legal stakeholders, including formal presentation of findings and explanation of ones analysis and conclusions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: presentation of findings in court... communicate their findings effectively... explain their analysis and conclusions

members.entity_description: Communication of forensic analytical results, particularly in legal or courtroom settings.
Forensic scientists interpretive work and the final inferences derived from evidence.

cluster_classes.class_description: High-level conclusions reached from forensic analysis of physical evidence, such as identifying suspects, determining cause of death, or detecting specific substances.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: forensic scientists can determine important details such as the identity of a suspect, the cause of death, or the presence of a particular substance

members.entity_description: Determination of who a suspected individual is based on forensic evidence.
Medical or physical reason a person died, inferred through forensic analysis.
Detection that a specific chemical or material exists in a forensic sample or location.

cluster_classes.class_description: Multifaceted, detailed datasets or information structures that require advanced analytical skills to interpret and draw conclusions, such as in forensic investigations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Forensic scientists must be able to analyze complex data and draw logical conclusions.

members.entity_description: Detailed, multifaceted forensic information that scientists analyze to reach conclusions.

args.justification: The entity 'analysis and conclusions' describes the cognitive/interpretive outcome of evidence analysis and fits better exclusively in 'Forensic Analytical Reasoning' rather than in 'Forensic Findings Communication', which should focus on the act of presenting results.

This class covers investigative problems and evidentiary indicators that are part of the broader forensic reasoning and case analysis workflow, so it should share a Class_Group with related reasoning, determination, and case-context classes.

This class represents forensic cases, legal issues, and the search for truth, which are the core contexts in which forensic reasoning and analysis are applied, so it belongs in the same Class_Group as other reasoning and outcome classes.

This class explicitly models the analytical reasoning processes and conclusions drawn from forensic evidence, forming the central cognitive component of forensic case analysis, so it should be grouped under 'Forensic Reasoning and Case Analysis'.

Although focused on communication acts, this class deals specifically with explaining and presenting forensic analytical results within cases, making it part of the broader forensic reasoning and case analysis pipeline.

This class captures high-level determinations (identity, cause of death, substance presence) that are direct outcomes of forensic reasoning about evidence in a case, so it naturally fits in the 'Forensic Reasoning and Case Analysis' Class_Group.

This class describes complex data that forensic scientists analyze when reasoning about cases, making it part of the same forensic reasoning and case analysis domain as the other classes in this cluster.

executed_decisions.justification: The entity 'analysis and conclusions' describes the cognitive/interpretive outcome of evidence analysis and fits better exclusively in 'Forensic Analytical Reasoning' rather than in 'Forensic Findings Communication', which should focus on the act of presenting results.

This class covers investigative problems and evidentiary indicators that are part of the broader forensic reasoning and case analysis workflow, so it should share a Class_Group with related reasoning, determination, and case-context classes.

This class represents forensic cases, legal issues, and the search for truth, which are the core contexts in which forensic reasoning and analysis are applied, so it belongs in the same Class_Group as other reasoning and outcome classes.

This class explicitly models the analytical reasoning processes and conclusions drawn from forensic evidence, forming the central cognitive component of forensic case analysis, so it should be grouped under 'Forensic Reasoning and Case Analysis'.

Although focused on communication acts, this class deals specifically with explaining and presenting forensic analytical results within cases, making it part of the broader forensic reasoning and case analysis pipeline.

This class captures high-level determinations (identity, cause of death, substance presence) that are direct outcomes of forensic reasoning about evidence in a case, so it naturally fits in the 'Forensic Reasoning and Case Analysis' Class_Group.

This class describes complex data that forensic scientists analyze when reasoning about cases, making it part of the same forensic reasoning and case analysis domain as the other classes in this cluster.

cluster_classes.class_description: Tangible items collected and examined in forensic investigations, such as fingerprints, firearms, and tool marks, used to identify suspects or reconstruct events.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: This evidence can range from fingerprints and DNA samples to firearms and tool marks.

members.entity_description: Unique ridge patterns from fingers used as physical evidence in forensic investigations.
Guns and related weapons examined as forensic evidence for criminal investigations.
Impressions or striations left by tools on surfaces, analyzed in forensic investigations.

cluster_classes.class_description: Microscopic or small physical materials, including the general category of trace evidence and specific examples such as fibers and hair, used to link people or objects to crime scenes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: trace evidence such as fibers or hair ... small or microscopic materials ... link people or objects to crime scenes

members.entity_description: Small or microscopic materials like fibers or hair that can link people or objects to crime scenes.
Small strands from materials like textiles that can serve as trace evidence in investigations.
Human or animal hair strands that can function as trace evidence in forensic analysis.

cluster_classes.class_description: Items or materials, physical or digital, collected in forensic investigations for preservation, examination, and potential use in court.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Physical or digital items and materials collected and handled in forensic investigations for documentation, preservation, and examination.

members.entity_description: Tangible materials or objects collected at a scene, such as biological traces, weapons, or trace particles, that are collected and analyzed by forensic science for investigations and presentation in court.
Physical or digital items and materials collected and handled in forensic investigations for documentation, preservation, and examination.

cluster_classes.class_description: Collected biological or material specimens that serve as evidence for forensic testing, including generic samples and DNA-specific samples.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: sample ... analyzed for drugs or toxins; evidence can range from fingerprints and DNA samples

members.entity_description: A collected portion of material, such as biological or chemical matter, analyzed for drugs or toxins.
Biological material containing genetic information collected for forensic identification.

args.justification: Assigning a shared Class_Group 'Forensic Evidence' to connect this physical evidence subtype with related forensic evidence classes in the same domain.
Trace evidence (fibers, hair, etc.) is a clear subtype of forensic evidence and should share the common Class_Group 'Forensic Evidence' with other related classes.

args.new_description: Umbrella class for forensic evidence, covering physical or digital items and materials collected and handled in forensic investigations for documentation, preservation, examination, and potential use in court.
args.justification: Clarifying this as the umbrella category for all forensic evidence (physical and digital) and aligning it in the shared Class_Group with its subtypes.

args.new_description: Collected biological or material specimens (e.g., general samples and DNA-specific samples) that serve as forensic evidence for laboratory testing and analysis.
args.justification: Positioning forensic samples as a specific category under the broader forensic evidence domain and updating description/type_hint to emphasize its role as a category of evidence.

The entity 'physical evidence' (tangible materials or objects) fits better under the 'Forensic Physical Evidence' class, which explicitly covers tangible forensic items such as fingerprints, firearms, and tool marks, while leaving 'General Forensic Evidence' as the umbrella class.

executed_decisions.justification: Assigning a shared Class_Group 'Forensic Evidence' to connect this physical evidence subtype with related forensic evidence classes in the same domain.
Trace evidence (fibers, hair, etc.) is a clear subtype of forensic evidence and should share the common Class_Group 'Forensic Evidence' with other related classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Umbrella class for forensic evidence, covering physical or digital items and materials collected and handled in forensic investigations for documentation, preservation, examination, and potential use in court.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarifying this as the umbrella category for all forensic evidence (physical and digital) and aligning it in the shared Class_Group with its subtypes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Collected biological or material specimens (e.g., general samples and DNA-specific samples) that serve as forensic evidence for laboratory testing and analysis.
executed_decisions.justification: Positioning forensic samples as a specific category under the broader forensic evidence domain and updating description/type_hint to emphasize its role as a category of evidence.

The entity 'physical evidence' (tangible materials or objects) fits better under the 'Forensic Physical Evidence' class, which explicitly covers tangible forensic items such as fingerprints, firearms, and tool marks, while leaving 'General Forensic Evidence' as the umbrella class.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts related to the process and conditions of examining, documenting, and preserving a crime scene and its evidence.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: documenting and preserving the integrity of the crime scene, as well as collecting and cataloging evidence

members.entity_description: Process of examining crime scenes to document conditions and collect evidence.
Condition of a crime scene remaining uncontaminated and unchanged during investigation.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes in forensic science focused on obtaining and working with physical evidence, including its initial collection and subsequent analytical examination.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: One of the key aspects of forensic science is the collection and analysis of physical evidence.

members.entity_description: Process of gathering physical evidence, identified as a key aspect of forensic science.
Examination and evaluation of physical evidence to draw conclusions in forensic science.

splits.name: Crime Scene Investigation
splits.description: Processes involved in examining and documenting a crime scene to collect evidence.

splits.name: Crime Scene Integrity
splits.description: Conditions and safeguards that keep a crime scene uncontaminated and unchanged during investigation.

args.justification: The original 'Crime Scene Handling' class mixes a procedural concept (crime scene investigation) with a state/condition concept (crime scene integrity); splitting produces two semantically coherent classes aligned with process vs condition.
args.remark: Source class ClsC_ffe4478e is left with no members after the split and can be reviewed for deprecation or repurposing.

args.new_description: Processes and procedures used to examine crime scenes, document conditions, and collect evidence while preserving the scene.
args.justification: Aligns the new split class with its procedural focus and assigns a shared Class_Group that will connect it to other forensic evidence workflow classes.

args.new_description: Conditions, controls, and policies that ensure a crime scene remains uncontaminated and unchanged throughout investigation.
args.justification: Clarifies the class as representing a state/condition concept and links it to the same overarching forensic procedures Class_Group.

args.new_description: Processes in forensic science focused on obtaining, preserving, and analyzing physical evidence from collection through examination.
args.justification: Keeps the class focused on end-to-end handling of physical evidence and assigns it to the same Class_Group as related crime scene procedure classes to reflect their shared forensic workflow domain.

executed_decisions.justification: The original 'Crime Scene Handling' class mixes a procedural concept (crime scene investigation) with a state/condition concept (crime scene integrity); splitting produces two semantically coherent classes aligned with process vs condition.
executed_decisions.remark: Source class ClsC_ffe4478e is left with no members after the split and can be reviewed for deprecation or repurposing.

executed_decisions.new_description: Processes and procedures used to examine crime scenes, document conditions, and collect evidence while preserving the scene.
executed_decisions.justification: Aligns the new split class with its procedural focus and assigns a shared Class_Group that will connect it to other forensic evidence workflow classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Conditions, controls, and policies that ensure a crime scene remains uncontaminated and unchanged throughout investigation.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarifies the class as representing a state/condition concept and links it to the same overarching forensic procedures Class_Group.

executed_decisions.new_description: Processes in forensic science focused on obtaining, preserving, and analyzing physical evidence from collection through examination.
executed_decisions.justification: Keeps the class focused on end-to-end handling of physical evidence and assigns it to the same Class_Group as related crime scene procedure classes to reflect their shared forensic workflow domain.

cluster_classes.class_description: Physical and institutional locations central to forensic practice, including where crimes occur and where evidence and findings are presented in legal proceedings.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: crime scene where a crime took place; court where forensic evidence and findings may be presented

members.entity_description: Judicial setting where legal proceedings occur and forensic evidence and findings may be presented.
Location where a crime took place and where forensic evidence is documented, preserved, and collected for analysis.

args.justification: The class groups physical and institutional locations specifically in forensic and legal practice (crime scene, court), so assigning the Class_Group 'Forensic Context & Locations' connects it to the broader forensic-domain context layer.

executed_decisions.justification: The class groups physical and institutional locations specifically in forensic and legal practice (crime scene, court), so assigning the Class_Group 'Forensic Context & Locations' connects it to the broader forensic-domain context layer.
